name: Tracy Alloway
tweet: @Simon_H77 Political/regulatory risk is key in my view. You can't fix this fast enough letting the market evolve its own pressure points at different speeds and standards for different companies/countries/etc.

name: Tracy Alloway
tweet: @KimBenabib Sure, except that's not what's happened. See for example, ESG concerns effectively punishing European energy firms vs U.S. energy firms by raising their funding costs.   https://t.co/gZKAaUd08S

name: Tracy Alloway
tweet: ESG is supposed to help solve a global problem but instead we‚Äôre creating an uneven patchwork of pressures and incentives that may lead to individually desirable outcomes (BP‚Äôs itself is cleaner) but terrible collective results (polluting businesses still exist).

name: Tracy Alloway
tweet: E.g. from the story: ‚ÄúNone of the three buyers on the other side of BP‚Äôs recent divestment deals discloses overall carbon data or has meaningful climate plans.‚Äù

name: Tracy Alloway
tweet: So big energy companies under pressure from the ESG craze sell problematic businesses to companies who are *NOT* disincentivized  from holding them. These are players who either don‚Äôt care about ESG or whose funding costs aren‚Äôt affected by them at all.

name: Tracy Alloway
tweet: This is one reason why ESG is really frustrating to me; it creates perverse incentives. BP is encouraged by ESG investors to reduce its own emissions & an easy way of doing that quickly is to just get rid of the most polluting businesses by selling them.

name: Tracy Alloway
tweet: MUST READ on why BP walking away from polluting businesses won't reduce global carbon emissions.   https://t.co/NV7k0Yi1B8 by @racheladhe & @rachaeldottle

name: Tracy Alloway
tweet: @MarkTimperman Total return swaps can allow you to get exposure to something that might otherwise be difficult to get exposure to (e.g. think of a U.S. fund that wants to buy a foreign stock/basket of stocks but doesn't want to jump through a bunch of hoops to get it)

name: Tracy Alloway
tweet: @RodFarva9 @creditsights See my comments under the chart...

name: Tracy Alloway
tweet: Not on this chart are non-US banks like Nomura and Credit Suisse. Share counts there look to have increased by about 100 million (similar to Morgan Stanley levels)

name: Tracy Alloway
tweet: A typical equity swap sees a bank by a stock on behalf of a fund & then pass the economic benefit of that stock back to the fund (in return for a nice fee)  So you can try to gauge Archegos exposure by looking at banks' reported holdings of equities like Viacom & @GSX.
